{{Infobox professional wrestler |name=2 Tuff Tony |image=2 Tuff Tony.jpg |caption=Tony in 2008. |names='''2 Tuff Tony''' |height=6 ft 0<ref name=jcp>{{cite web|url=http://www.juggalowrestling.com/iframe.php?page_id=jcw_profile_2_tuff_tony|title=2 Tuff Tony|publisher=Psychopathic Sports|accessdate=2008-08-29|date=April 22, 2008|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081214115827/http://www.juggalowrestling.com/iframe.php?page_id=jcw_profile_2_tuff_tony|archive-date=2008-12-14|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> |weight=240<ref name=jcp/><ref name=bs/> |birth_name = Anthony Borcherding |birth_date = {{birth date and age|1974|06|06|mf=yes}}<ref name=bs/> |birth_place =[[Louisville, Kentucky]]<ref name=jcp/> |resides= Louisville, Kentucky |billed= |children = 2 |trainer=[[The Moondogs (professional wrestling)|The Moondogs]]<ref name="WWD9">{{cite video |people=2 Tuff Tony and Corporal Robinson (Interviewees) |date=2010-09-24 |title=Wrestling with Disaster 9 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d8PnAoomNAw |medium=internet production |publisher=Legit Wrestling |accessdate=2010-09-29 }}</ref> |debut= May 23, 1996<ref name=bs/> |retired= |}} '''Anthony Borcherding'''<ref name=bs>{{cite web|url=http://bodyslamming.com/other/2tuff.html|title=2 Tuff Tony profile|publisher=Bodyslamming.com|accessdate=2008-08-29}}</ref> (born June 6, 1974), better known by his [[ring name]] '''2 Tuff Tony''', is an American [[professional wrestling|professional wrestler]] best known for his [[hardcore wrestling]] style. Throughout his professional wrestling career, Tony has wrestled for various wrestling promotions, including [[Independent Wrestling Association Mid-South]], [[Combat Zone Wrestling]], [[Big Japan Pro Wrestling]], and [[Juggalo Championship Wrestling]]. He is currently employed by Juggalo Championship Wrestling.
In his professional wrestling career, Tony is an eight-time Heavyweight champion, having won the BBW Wrestling Heavyweight Championship once, ICW Heavyweight Championship once, [[IWA Mid-South Heavyweight Championship]] twice, [[JCW Heavyweight Championship]] three times, and MRW Heavyweight Championship once. In addition to these championships, he has won the [[Dramatic Dream Team]] [[Ironman Heavymetalweight Championship]] once and [[IWA Mid-South Hardcore Championship]] thrice, the latter of which he is the final recognized champion. Tony is also the 2006 [[IWA Mid-South King of the Deathmatch#Double Death Tag Team Tournament 2006|IWA Mid-South Double Death Tag Team Tournament winner]] with [[Mad Man Pondo]].
==Professional wrestling career==
===Early career (1996-1999)=== Tony's friends Robert and Jerry traveled to [[Arkansas]] to train with professional wrestlers [[The Moondogs]] and invited him to come along.<ref name="WWD9"/> After watching several training sessions, Tony was invited into the ring. He soon began training alongside his friends, free of charge, because [[Moondog Spot]] felt that Tony "was a natural for the business."<ref name="WWD9"/> Tony started wrestling in [[Indiana]] in a small bingo hall, where he first met wrestler [[Steve Robinson (wrestler)|Corporal Robinson]].<ref name="WWD9"/> He, Robinson, and [[Mad Man Pondo]] began traveling throughout the country together.<ref name="WWD10">{{cite video |people=2 Tuff Tony and Corporal Robinson (Interviewees) |date=2010-09-27 |title=Wrestling with Disaster 10 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qIvaXDWOgOM |medium=internet production |publisher=Legit Wrestling |accessdate=2010-09-29 }}</ref> Video distribution company Smart Mark Video helped the trio gain national exposure.<ref name="WWD10"/>
===Independent Wrestling Association Mid-South (1999-2007)=== Tony began working for [[Independent Wrestling Association Mid-South]] (IWA-MS) in 1999. He wrestled his first match against Rolling Hard, where he was introduced to the [[hardcore wrestling]] style of the company.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio">{{cite video |people=Mr. Wrestling (interviewer), 2 Tuff Tony (interviewee) |date=2011-03-02 |title=JCW's 2 Tuff Tony on Ultraviolent Radio 3-2-2011 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hhRaIOS28ts |medium=Internet Interview |accessdate=2011-03-17 }}</ref> Seeing that Tony had never wrestled in the hardcore style before, Mad Man Pondo requested to work with him in matches.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/> The promotion's owner, [[Ian Rotten]], supported the idea and booked the two in a rivalry.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/> Pondo acquainted him to the proper techniques of hardcore wrestling, and Tony later recalled that Pondo "took good care of me" in their matches.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/>
On April 29, 1999, Tony defeated Pondo for the [[IWA Mid-South Hardcore Championship]].<ref name="IWAHardcore">{{cite web| url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/ky/iwams/iwams-hc.html |title=Independent Wrestling Association Mid-South Hardcore Title |accessdate=2011-03-17 |publisher=Puroreso Dojo}}</ref> He lost the championship on May 14 to Pondo, but won it back the following day.<ref name="IWAHardcore"/> The following February he lost the championship, but won the [[IWA Mid-South Heavyweight Championship]] two weeks later.<ref name="IWAHardcore"/><ref name="IWAHeavyweight">{{cite web| url=http://www.wrestling-titles.com/us/ky/iwams/iwams-h.html |title=Independent Wrestling Association Mid-South Heavyweight Title |accessdate=2011-03-17 |publisher=Puroreso Dojo}}</ref> On March 4, he defeated Pondo and Delilah Starr to unify the IWA-MS Hardcore and Heavyweight Championships.<ref name="IWAHardcore"/><ref name="IWAHeavyweight"/> Two weeks later, Tony lost the championship.<ref name="IWAHeavyweight"/> He won it for a second time the following March 2, before losing it to Mitch Page a month later.<ref name="IWAHeavyweight"/>
In 2006, Tony and Mad Man Pondo took part in the first [[IWA Mid-South King of the Deathmatch#IWA Mid-South Double Death Tag Team Tournament|Double Death Tag Team Tournament]], though they weren't told which team would win the tournament.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/> They defeated Children of Pain then Dysfunction and Corporal Robinson to make it to the finals. In the finals, Tony and Pondo defeated Tough Crazy Bastards to be crowned the first Double Death Tag Team Tournament champions.
===Juggalo Championship Wrestling (1999–present)=== In 1997, Tony wrestled for Insane Clown Posse at the event ''ICP's Strangle-Mania Live''.<ref name="BehindthePaint353">{{cite book |last=Bruce |first=Joseph |author2=Hobey Echlin |editor=Nathan Fostey |title=ICP: Behind the Paint |date=August 2003 |edition=2nd |publisher=Psychopathic Records |location=Royal Oak, Michigan |isbn=0974184608 |pages=353–365 |chapter=Life on the Road }}</ref> Two years later, he, Robinson, and Mad Man Pondo wrestled at the Dan Curtis Memorial, an independent wrestling [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#B|booker]] who had recently worked for Insane Clown Posse.<ref name="WWD10"/><ref name="BehindthePaint398">{{cite book |last=Bruce |first=Joseph |authorlink=Violent J|author2=Hobey Echlin |editor=Nathan Fostey |title=ICP: Behind the Paint |date=August 2003 |edition=2nd |publisher=Psychopathic Records |location=Royal Oak, Michigan |isbn=0974184608 |pages=398–413 |chapter=Taking Bumps }}</ref> Several days after the event, Tony, Robinson, and Pondo were booked to wrestle for Insane Clown Posse's first [[Juggalo Championship Wrestling]] show.<ref name="WWD10"/> Video of the event was later released nationally. Tony continued wrestling for Juggalo Championship Wrestling, including matches at the [[Gathering of the Juggalos]] festivals and two other videos released by the company.
Tony went on tour with JCW in 2007 to film the [[internet]] [[Professional wrestling|wrestling]] show [[Juggalo Championship Wrestling#SlamTV!|SlamTV!]], where he was involved in a rivalry with [[Tracy Smothers]].<ref name="JCW SLAM TV, Volume 1">{{cite video|date=2007-09-18|title=JCW SLAM TV, Volume 1|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1194583|medium=DVD|publisher=Psychopathic Video|location=Royal Oak, Michigan|accessdate=2008-11-15}}</ref> Tracy attacked Tony in the sixth episode, causing Tony to be knocked out of action for several weeks.<ref name="JCW SLAM TV, Volume 1"/> Per storyline, Smothers was arrested just days before Tony's return on the eighth episode, leaving Tony with no way to seek revenge.<ref name="JCW SLAM TV, Volume 1"/> Tony was attacked by [[Bull Pain]] at East Side Wars, but later defeated him in a [[Hillerich & Bradsby|Louisville Slugger]] match at [[Bloodymania (2007)|Bloodymania]].<ref name="JCW SLAM TV, Volume 2">{{cite video|date=2007-10-30|title=JCW SLAM TV, Volume 2|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1194584/|medium=DVD|publisher=Psychopathic Video|location=Royal Oak, Michigan|accessdate=2008-11-15}}</ref> On January 26, 2008, Tony and [[Violent J]] won the [[JCW Tag Team Championship]]. However, their victory was declared void, stricken from the record, and the title was vacated.<ref name="Jan262008">{{cite web |title=JCW January 26, 2008 |url=http://www.cagematch.de/?id=1&nr=18279 |publisher=Cagematch |accessdate=13 August 2008 |language=German}}</ref><ref name="SlamTV2-1">{{cite episode |title=Slam TV Season 2 - Episode 1 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=m1ph1KX5BiQ |series=SlamTV! |credits=Creator and Producer: [[Insane Clown Posse]] |location=Toledo, Ohio |airdate=2008-06-16 |season=2 }}</ref><ref name="The Main Event Feb 22">{{cite episode |title=Feb 22, 2011|series=The Main Event |url=http://wfuckoffradio.com/wpress/?p=51 |credits=Presenters: [[Violent J]], 2 Tuff Tony, and [[Steve Robinson (wrestler)|Corporal Robinson]] |station=WFKO |airdate=2011-02-22 |minutes= 3:21:00|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110512054432/http://wfuckoffradio.com/the-main-event|archivedate=May 12, 2011 }}</ref>
Tony continued his rivalry with Tracy Smothers into season two of SlamTV! In the first episode, both men faced off in a match which saw Tracy win after a fast count by the referee, who was later revealed as Tracy's [[Legitimacy (family law)|illegitimate]] daughter, [[Mickie Knuckles|Isabella]].<ref name="SlamTV2-1"/> Two weeks later, Tracy caught Isabella listening to [[Boondox]], the rapper who sings Tony's entrance music.<ref name="SlamTV2-3">{{cite episode|title=Slam TV Season 2 - Episode 3|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VH6s_95TFHA|series=SlamTV!|credits=Creator and Producer: [[Insane Clown Posse]]|location=Springfield, Illinois|airdate=2008-07-25|season=2}}</ref> The following week, Tony attacked Smothers after his match. Tracy later caught Isabella engaging in sexual actions with Boondox, through storyline, and assaulted him.<ref name="SlamTV2-4">{{cite episode|title=Slam TV Season 2 - Episode 4|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f9B7oNXlKuM|series=SlamTV!|credits=Creator and Producer: [[Insane Clown Posse]]|location=St. Louis, Missouri|airdate=2008-07-31|season=2}}</ref> Tracy and Isabella Smothers were then scheduled face Boondox and 2 Tuff Tony at [[Bloodymania II]].<ref name="SlamTV2-5">{{cite episode |title=Slam TV Season 2 - Episode 5 |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LT7cmP_w0nQ |series=SlamTV! |credits=Creator and Producer: [[Insane Clown Posse]] |location=Milwaukee, Wisconsin |airdate=2008-08-04 |season=2 }}</ref> However, Isabella was replaced by [[Bull Pain]] after she injured her leg, and Smothers and Pain lost to Tony and Boondox.
At the 2008 Hallowicked After-Party, Tony joined the group the [[Juggalo World Order]]. On November 9, the Juggalo World Order (Scott Hall, Shaggy 2 Dope, Violent J, 2 Tuff Tony, and Corporal Robinson) "invaded" [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]]'s [[Turning Point (2008 wrestling)|Turning Point]] PPV by purchasing front row tickets to the event. They proceeded to promote their faction by flashing their JWO jerseys, which each member had on, before being removed from the building.<ref name="PWTorch Nov 9">{{cite web |url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/TNA_News_1/article_27798.shtml |last=Caldwell |first=James |title=Scott Hall appears on camera with ICP at tonight's TNA PPV |accessdate=10 November 2008 |publisher=ProWrestlingTorch |date=2008-11-09 }}</ref><ref name="The Main Event Nov 11">{{cite episode|title=November 11, 2008 |series=The Main Event |url=http://wfuckoffradio.com/wfko.php/shows/15 |credits=Presenters: [[Violent J]], 2 Tuff Tony, and [[Corporal Robinson]] |station=WFKO |airdate=2008-11-11 |minutes=48:18 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120126090212/http://www.psychopathicradio.com/site/ |archive-date=January 26, 2012 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> At [[Bloodymania III]], 2 Tuff Tony was defeated by [[Viscera (wrestler)|Viscera]] in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Loser Leaves Town match|"Loser leaves JCW"]] match with [[Terry Funk]] as special guest referee due to interference by [[Balls Mahoney]].<ref name="The Main Event July 20">{{cite episode|title=July 20, 2010| series=The Main Event| url=http://wfuckoffradio.com/wfko.php/shows/15| credits=Presenters: [[Violent J]], 2 Tuff Tony, and [[Corporal Robinson]]| station=WFKO| airdate=2010-07-20|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100725115222/http://www.wfuckoffradio.com/wfko.php/shows/15|archivedate=2010-07-25}}</ref> Tony was reinstated two months later under the conditions that he start at the bottom, receive no title matches for several months, and cannot compete at any ''Bloodymania'' events.<ref name="The Main Event July 20"/><ref name="The Main Event March 18">{{cite episode |title=March 18, 2010|series=The Main Event |url=http://wfuckoffradio.com/wfko.php/shows/15 |credits=Presenters: [[Violent J]], 2 Tuff Tony, and [[Corporal Robinson]] |station=WFKO |airdate=2010-03-18 |minutes= 1:20:50 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100328093423/http://www.wfuckoffradio.com/wfko.php/shows/15|archivedate=2010-03-28}}</ref>
That October at Hallowicked After-Party, Tony debuted under the name 2 Strong John while wearing a [[Wrestling mask|mask]] and wrestled against Balls Mahoney.<ref name="The Main Event March 18"/> At Oddball Bonanza on March 20, 2010, he wrestled as 2 Tuff Tony to take on [[Trent Acid|"Holy" Trent Acid]].<ref name="The Main Event March 18"/> During the match, he debuted his newest finisher, an [[Piledriver (professional wrestling)#Package piledriver|inverted sitout package piledriver]] which he calls Dick for Dinner.<ref name="The Main Event March 18"/><ref name="pwnewsnow">{{cite web|url=http://www.pwnewsnow.com/2010/icps-juggalo-championship-wrestling-results/ |title=ICP's Juggalo Championship Wrestling Results |author=Ric Stevens |date=2010-03-22 |publisher=PWNewsNow |accessdate=21 March 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100325002718/http://www.pwnewsnow.com/2010/icps-juggalo-championship-wrestling-results/ |archivedate=25 March 2010 |deadurl=yes }}</ref> [[Bloodymania IV]] saw the team of [[Balls Mahoney]] and the masked Hollywood Chuck Hogan defeat the team of Mad Man Pondo and [[Necro Butcher]]. Following the match, Hollywood Chuck Hogan unmasked himself to reveal that he was actually 2 Tuff Tony.<ref name="BloodymaniaIV">{{cite web|title=Gathering of the Juggalos Wrestling Recap! |url=http://www.juggalowrestling.com/iframe.php?page_id=home&cat_id=home#a1 |publisher=Psychopathic Sports |date=2010-09-03 |accessdate=2010-09-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100212220752/http://www.juggalowrestling.com/iframe.php?page_id=home&cat_id=home |archivedate=2010-02-12 }}</ref><ref name="GOTJ2010">{{cite web|title=Violent J's Gathering Report |url=http://www.insaneclownposse.com/general-news/violent-js-gathering-report/ |publisher=Psychopathic Records |date=2008-05-22 |accessdate=2009-05-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100824102809/http://www.insaneclownposse.com/general-news/violent-js-gathering-report/ |archivedate=2010-08-24 }}</ref> Tony then attacked Mahoney, leaving him beat down in the middle of the ring.<ref name="BloodymaniaIV"/><ref name="GOTJ2010"/>
Tony faced [[Sabu (wrestler)|Sabu]] at the 2011 event Monster's Island. Sabu, who recently aligned himself with villainous manager Charlie Brown, defeated Tony and continued to attack him after the match ended.<ref name="MonstersIsland">{{cite web |url=http://www.cagematch.de/?id=1&nr=61614 |title=JCW Monster's Island |publisher=Philip Kreikenbohm |accessdate=2011-04-11| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110513024804/http://www.cagematch.de/?id=1&nr=61614| archivedate= 13 May 2011 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref> The two wrestled again at Up in Smoke in a match where [[Rob Conway]] was hired by Brown to attack Tony.<ref name="UpinSmoke">{{cite web |url=http://pwinsider.com/ViewArticle.php?id=57294&p=2 |title=Complete JCW Up in Smoke Internet PPV Coverage: New JCW Champions Crowned, Sabu, Rhino, Zach Gowen and More |author=Mike Johnson |date=2011-04-20 |publisher=PWInsider.com |accessdate=2011-04-20}}</ref> He and [[Rhino (wrestler)|Rhino]] defeated Sabu and Conway at [[St. Andrews Brawl]], where Tony was later named number one contender for the [[JCW Heavyweight Championship]].<ref name="StAndrewsBrawl">{{cite web |url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/otherppvs/article_49895.shtml |title=Radican's JCW "St. Andrews Brawl" review 5/4: U-Gene vs. Goodie, Cabana vs. Weedman, Rydas vs. Haters |author=Sean Radican |date=2011-05-07 |publisher= TDH Communications Inc. |accessdate=2011-05-08}}</ref> At Send in the Clowns, Tony defeated Butler Geeves to become JCW Heavyweight Champion.<ref name="SendintheClowns">{{cite web |url=http://pwinsider.com/article/59486/complete-jcw-send-in-the-clowns-internet-ppv-coverage-new-jcw-champ-crowned-rhino-jimmy-jacobs-officer-colt-cabana-necro-butcher-tracy-smothers-and-more.html?p=1 |title=Complete JCW 'Send in the Clowns' Internet PPV |author=Matt Carter |date=2011-06-30 |publisher=PWInsider.com |accessdate=2011-07-04}}</ref> The following month at Above The Law, Tony lost the championship to [[Colt Cabana|Officer Colt Cabana]].<ref name="Above The Law">{{cite web |url=http://www.pwinsider.com/ViewArticle.php?id=60046&p=4 |title=Complete Juggalo Championship Wrestling 'Above The Law' iPPV Coverage |author=Matt Carter |date=2011-07-20 |publisher=PWInsider.com |accessdate=2011-07-21}}</ref>
At the Hatchet Attacks PPV on May 26, 2012, 2 Tuff Tony defeated [[Kongo Kong]] to win the vacant JCW Heavyweight Championship, making him champion for a second time.<ref name="HatchetAttacks">{{cite web |url=http://pwtorch.com/artman2/publish/otherppvs/article_61818.shtml |title=RADICAN'S JCW "HATCHET ATTACKS" iPPV REPORT 5/26 - virtual time coverage from Farmington, N.M. |author=Sean Radican |date=2012-05-26 |publisher=pwtorch.com |accessdate=2012-06-29}}</ref> On October 31, 2013, Tony was defeated by [[Necro Butcher]] in a title match.<ref>http://www.cagematch.de/?id=1&nr=103074</ref> On May 4, 2014, Tony defeated Krimson to win the vacant JCW Heavyweight Championship. On April 19, 2015, Tony was defeated by Weedman in a title match.
2 Tuff appears as himself with former JCW tag partner Corporal Robinson in the underground wrestling documentary Wrestling with Disaster, a feature-length film that highlights an indy wrestling show gone horribly awry. The production is currently streaming at youtube.com/LegitProWrestling <ref>|url=//youtu.be/MSg-lhxOhRM|</ref>
===Big Japan Pro Wrestling (2000-2006)=== Tony was brought to [[Big Japan Pro Wrestling]] in 2000 by Mad Man Pondo, at the time the American booker for the company.<ref name="WWD10"/><ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/> Tony trained at local [[dojo]]s and helped set up chairs at the company, which earned him the respect of the wrestlers.<ref name="WWD10"/> During his first tour, Tony wrestled in mostly singles matches and learned the Japanese style of wrestling.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/> In his third tour, he and Pondo formed the tag team Baka Gaijin, Japanese for Stupid Foreigners.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/> The team was well received by both the Japanese crowd and the Japanese wrestlers.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/> They continued to wrestle multiple tours together from 2001 to 2006.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/>
==Personal life== Borcherding resides in his hometown of [[Louisville, Kentucky]]. He has one daughter and one son. He has suffered multiple injuries throughout his career, including roughly 30 [[concussion]]s, a split [[artery]] in his wrist, a broken leg, both eyebrows being split, and permanent scarring on his forehead.<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/> In 2001, Tony and Corporal Robinson signed with [[Extreme Championship Wrestling]], but the company filed bankruptcy that same day.<ref name="WWD10"/> Though they were not in the company long, the duo had become (and still remain) friends with many of the wrestlers.<ref name="WWD10"/>
==Championships and accomplishments== *'''Bad 2 The Bone Wrestling''' **BBW Wrestling Heavyweight Championship (1 time)<ref name=jcp/> *'''[[Dramatic Dream Team]]''' **[[Ironman Heavymetalweight Championship]] ([[Ironman Heavymetalweight Championship#Title history|1 time]]) *'''[[Independent Wrestling Association Mid-South]]''' **[[IWA Mid-South Hardcore Championship]] ([[IWA Mid-South Hardcore Championship#Title history|3 times]])<ref name=bs/> **[[IWA Mid-South Heavyweight Championship]] ([[IWA Mid-South Heavyweight Championship#Title history|2 times]])<ref name=jcp/> **[[IWA Mid-South King of the Deathmatch#IWA Mid-South Double Death Tag Team Tournament|Double Death Tag Team Tournament]] ([[IWA Mid-South King of the Deathmatch#Double Death Tag Team Tournament 2006|2006]])<ref name="UltraviolentRadio"/> - with [[Mad Man Pondo]] *'''Insane Wrestling Federation''' **IWF Tag Team Championship (2 times)<ref name=bs/> *'''[[Juggalo Championship Wrestling]]''' **[[JCW Heavyweight Championship]] (3 times)<ref name="SendintheClowns"/> *'''Midwest Renegade Wrestling''' **MRW Heavyweight Championship (1 time)<ref name=jcp/> *'''Other titles''' **ICW Heavyweight Championship<ref name=bs/> **ICW Tag Team Championship<ref name=bs/>

The '''Amino Acid-Polyamine-Organocation (APC) Family''' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.a.3 TC# 2.A.3]) of transport proteins includes members that function as solute:cation symporters and solute:solute antiporters.<ref name="Saier 2000">{{cite journal | vauthors = Saier MH | title = Families of transmembrane transporters selective for amino acids and their derivatives | journal = Microbiology | volume = 146 ( Pt 8) | issue = 8 | pages = 1775–95 | date = August 2000 | pmid = 10931885 | doi = 10.1099/00221287-146-8-1775 }}</ref><ref name="Wong 2012">{{cite journal | vauthors = Wong FH, Chen JS, Reddy V, Day JL, Shlykov MA, Wakabayashi ST, Saier MH | title = The amino acid-polyamine-organocation superfamily | journal = Journal of Molecular Microbiology and Biotechnology | volume = 22 | issue = 2 | pages = 105–13 | date = 2012 | pmid = 22627175 | doi = 10.1159/000338542 }}</ref><ref name=Schweikhard>{{cite journal | vauthors = Schweikhard ES, Ziegler CM | title = Amino acid secondary transporters: toward a common transport mechanism | journal = Current Topics in Membranes | volume = 70 | pages = 1–28 | date = 2012 | pmid = 23177982 | doi = 10.1016/B978-0-12-394316-3.00001-6 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Perland E, Fredriksson R | title = Classification Systems of Secondary Active Transporters | journal = Trends in Pharmacological Sciences | volume = 38 | issue = 3 | pages = 305–315 | date = March 2017 | pmid = 27939446 | doi = 10.1016/j.tips.2016.11.008 }}</ref> They occur in bacteria, archaea, fungi, unicellular eukaryotic protists, slime molds, plants and animals.<ref name="Saier 2000"/> They vary in length, being as small as 350 residues and as large as 850 residues. The smaller proteins are generally of prokaryotic origin while the larger ones are of eukaryotic origin. Most of them possess twelve transmembrane α-helical spanners but have a re-entrant loop involving TMSs 2 and 3.<ref name=Gasol>{{cite journal | vauthors = Gasol E, Jiménez-Vidal M, Chillarón J, Zorzano A, Palacín M | title = Membrane topology of system xc- light subunit reveals a re-entrant loop with substrate-restricted accessibility | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 279 | issue = 30 | pages = 31228–36 | date = July 2004 | pmid = 15151999 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.M402428200 }}</ref><ref name=TCDB>{{cite web|last1=Saier|first1=MH Jr.|title=2.A.3 The Amino Acid-Polyamine-Organocation (APC) Superfamily|url=http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3|website=Transporter Classification Database|publisher=Saier Lab Bioinformatics Group / SDSC}}</ref> The [[APC Superfamily]] was established to encompass a wider range of homologues.
==Members of APC Family==
Members of one subfamily within the APC family ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.9#2.A.3.9 SGP; TC# 2.A.3.9]) are amino acid receptors rather than transporters <ref name=Cabrera>{{cite journal | vauthors = Cabrera-Martinez RM, Tovar-Rojo F, Vepachedu VR, Setlow P | title = Effects of overexpression of nutrient receptors on germination of spores of Bacillus subtilis | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 185 | issue = 8 | pages = 2457–64 | date = April 2003 | pmid = 12670969 | pmc = 152624 | doi = 10.1128/jb.185.8.2457-2464.2003 }}</ref> and are truncated at their C-termini, relative to the transporters, having 10 TMSs.<ref name=Jack>{{cite journal | vauthors = Jack DL, Paulsen IT, Saier MH | title = The amino acid/polyamine/organocation (APC) superfamily of transporters specific for amino acids, polyamines and organocations | journal = Microbiology | volume = 146 ( Pt 8) | issue = 8 | pages = 1797–814 | date = August 2000 | pmid = 10931886 | doi = 10.1099/00221287-146-8-1797 }}</ref>
The eukaryotic members of another subfamily ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.3#2.A.3.3 CAT; TC# 2.A.3.3]) and the members of a prokaryotic subfamily ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.11#2.A.3.11 AGT; TC #2.A.3.11]) have 14 TMSs.<ref name=Lorca>{{cite journal | vauthors = Lorca G, Winnen B, Saier MH | title = Identification of the L-aspartate transporter in Bacillus subtilis | journal = Journal of Bacteriology | volume = 185 | issue = 10 | pages = 3218–22 | date = May 2003 | pmid = 12730183 | pmc = 154055 | doi = 10.1128/jb.185.10.3218-3222.2003 }}</ref>
The larger eukaryotic and archaeal proteins possess N- and C-terminal hydrophilic extensions. Some animal proteins, for example, those in the LAT subfamily ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.8#2.A.3.8 TC# 2.A.3.8]) including [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.8.2 ASUR4 (gbY12716)] and [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.8.3 SPRM1 (gbL25068)] associate with a type 1 transmembrane glycoprotein that is essential for insertion or activity of the permease and forms a disulfide bridge with it. These glycoproteins include the CD98 heavy chain protein of ''Mus musculus (gbU25708)'' and the orthologous 4F2 cell surface antigen heavy chain of ''Homo sapiens (spP08195).'' The latter protein is required for the activity of the cystine/glutamate antiporter ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.8.5 2.A.3.8.5]), which maintains cellular redox balance and cysteine/glutathione levels.<ref name="Sato 2005">{{cite journal | vauthors = Sato H, Shiiya A, Kimata M, Maebara K, Tamba M, Sakakura Y, Makino N, Sugiyama F, Yagami K, Moriguchi T, Takahashi S, Bannai S | title = Redox imbalance in cystine/glutamate transporter-deficient mice | journal = The Journal of Biological Chemistry | volume = 280 | issue = 45 | pages = 37423–9 | date = November 2005 | pmid = 16144837 | doi = 10.1074/jbc.m506439200 }}</ref> They are members of the rBAT family of mammalian proteins ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=8.A.9 TC #8.A.9]).
Two APC family members, LAT1 and LAT2 ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.8.7 TC #2.A.3.8.7]), transport a neurotoxicant, the methylmercury-L-cysteine complex, by [[molecular mimicry]].<ref name=SimWillis>{{cite journal | vauthors = Simmons-Willis TA, Koh AS, Clarkson TW, Ballatori N | title = Transport of a neurotoxicant by molecular mimicry: the methylmercury-L-cysteine complex is a substrate for human L-type large neutral amino acid transporter (LAT) 1 and LAT2 | journal = The Biochemical Journal | volume = 367 | issue = Pt 1 | pages = 239–46 | date = October 2002 | pmid = 12117417 | pmc = 1222880 | doi = 10.1042/bj20020841 }}</ref>
Hip1 of ''S. cerevisiae'' ([http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.1.5 TC #2.A.3.1.5]) has been implicated in heavy metal transport.
===Subfamilies===
Subfamilies of the APC family, and the proteins in these families, can be found in the [http://www.tcdb.org/search/result.php?tc=2.A.3.9 Transporter Classification Database]:<ref name=TCDB/>
*2.A.3.1: The Amino Acid Transporter (AAT) Family *2.A.3.2: The Basic Amino Acid/Polyamine Antiporter (APA) Family *2.A.3.3: The Cationic Amino Acid Transporter (CAT) Family *2.A.3.4: The Amino Acid/Choline Transporter (ACT) Family *2.A.3.5: The Ethanolamine Transporter (EAT) Family *2.A.3.6: The Archaeal/Bacterial Transporter (ABT) Family *2.A.3.7: The Glutamate:GABA Antiporter (GGA) Family *2.A.3.8: The L-type Amino Acid Transporter (LAT) Family (Many LAT family members function as heterooligomers with rBAT and/or 4F2hc (TC #8.A.9)) *2.A.3.9: The Spore Germination Protein (SGP) Family *2.A.3.10: The Yeast Amino Acid Transporter (YAT) Family *2.A.3.11: The Aspartate/Glutamate Transporter (AGT) Family *2.A.3.12: The Polyamine:H+ Symporter (PHS) Family *2.A.3.13: The Amino Acid Efflux (AAE) Family *2.A.3.14: The Unknown APC-1 (U-APC1) Family *2.A.3.15: The Unknown APC-2 (U-APC2) Family
==Structure and Function== Based on 3-D structures of APC superfamily members, Rudnick (2011) has proposed the pathway for transport and suggested a "''rocking bundle"'' mechanism.<ref name="TCDB" /><ref name="Forrest">{{cite journal | vauthors = Forrest LR, Rudnick G | title = The rocking bundle: a mechanism for ion-coupled solute flux by symmetrical transporters | journal = Physiology | volume = 24 | issue = 6 | pages = 377–86 | date = December 2009 | pmid = 19996368 | pmc = 3012352 | doi = 10.1152/physiol.00030.2009 }}</ref><ref name="Rudnick 2011">{{cite journal | vauthors = Rudnick G | title = Cytoplasmic permeation pathway of neurotransmitter transporters | journal = Biochemistry | volume = 50 | issue = 35 | pages = 7462–75 | date = September 2011 | pmid = 21774491 | pmc = 3164596 | doi = 10.1021/bi200926b }}</ref>
===Transport Reactions=== Transport reactions generally catalyzed by APC Superfamily members include:<ref name=TCDB/>
::Solute:proton symport Solute (out) + nH<sup>+</sup> (out) → Solute (in) + nH<sup>+</sup> (in).
::Solute:solute antiport Solute-1 (out) + Solute-2 (in) ⇌ Solute-1 (in) + Solute-2 (out).
== See also == *[[APC Superfamily]] *[[Transporter Classification Database]] *[[Membrane transport protein]]

'''Antenatal steroids''' (or '''antenatal corticosteroids''') are [[medication]]s given to pregnant women expecting preterm delivery. They have been shown to reduce the morbidity and mortality of [[hyaline membrane disease]].<ref name="pmid20348115">{{cite journal|last=Mwansa-Kambafwile|first=J.|author2=Cousens, S.|author3= Hansen, T.|author4= Lawn, J. E.|title=Antenatal steroids in preterm labour for the prevention of neonatal deaths due to complications of preterm birth|journal=International Journal of Epidemiology|date=26 March 2010|volume=39|issue=Supplement 1|pages=i122–i133|doi=10.1093/ije/dyq029|pmid=20348115|url=http://ije.oxfordjournals.org/content/39/suppl_1/i122.full|pmc=2845868}}</ref> They have also been shown to have definite beneficial effect even in conditions of [[Premature rupture of membranes|preterm premature rupture of membranes]] (PPROM).<ref name="pmid21508704">{{cite journal|last=Vidaeff|first=AC|author2=Ramin, SM|title=Antenatal corticosteroids after preterm premature rupture of membranes|journal=Clinical obstetrics and gynecology|date=Jun 2011|volume=54|issue=2|pages=337–43|doi=10.1097/GRF.0b013e318217d85b|pmid=21508704}}</ref>
The effectiveness of antenatal corticosteroids in preventing neonatal hyaline membrane disease and reducing mortality in premature infants was first demonstrated by Sir [[Graham Liggins]] and Ross Howie in 1972.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Liggins|first1=GC|last2=Howie|first2=RN|title=A controlled trial of antepartum glucocorticoid treatment for prevention of the respiratory distress syndrome in premature infants.|journal=Pediatrics|date=October 1972|volume=50|issue=4|pages=515-525|pmid=4561295}}</ref>
Current evidence suggests that giving antenatal corticosteroids reduces late miscarriages and baby deaths. The baby is also less likely to have respiratory distress syndrome (difficulty breathing), or need assistance breathing (mechanical ventilation).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Roberts|first1=D|last2=Brown|first2=J|last3=Medley|first3=N|last4=Dalziel|first4=SR|title=Antenatal corticosteroids for accelerating fetal lung maturation for women at risk of preterm birth.|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=21 March 2017|volume=3|pages=CD004454|pmid=28321847|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD004454.pub3}}</ref> They are also less likely to have (bleeding on the brain) [[intraventricular hemorrhage]],<ref name="pmid19544249">{{cite journal |vauthors=Abbasi S, Oxford C, Gerdes J, Sehdev H, Ludmir J |title=Antenatal Corticosteroids Prior to 24 Weeks' Gestation and Neonatal Outcome of Extremely Low Birth Weight Infants |journal=Am J Perinatol |volume=27 |issue=1 |pages=61–66 |date=January 2010 |pmid=19544249 |doi=10.1055/s-0029-1223269 |url=http://www.thieme-connect.com/DOI/DOI?10.1055/s-0029-1223269}}</ref><ref name="pmid7892866">{{cite journal|last=Ment|first=LR|author2=Oh, W|author3= Ehrenkranz, RA|author4= Philip, AG|author5= Duncan, CC|author6= Makuch, RW|title=Antenatal steroids, delivery mode, and intraventricular hemorrhage in preterm infants.|journal=American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology|date=Mar 1995|volume=172|issue=3|pages=795–800|pmid=7892866|doi=10.1016/0002-9378(95)90001-2}}</ref> NEC, or systemic infections (infections affecting the whole body) in the first two days of their life.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Roberts|first1=D|last2=Brown|first2=J|last3=Medley|first3=N|last4=Dalziel|first4=SR|title=Antenatal corticosteroids for accelerating fetal lung maturation for women at risk of preterm birth.|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=21 March 2017|volume=3|pages=CD004454|pmid=28321847|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD004454.pub3}}</ref> Steroids do not appear to increase the number of women who develop infection of the fetal membranes (chorioamnionitis) or of the womb (endometritis).<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Roberts|first1=D|last2=Brown|first2=J|last3=Medley|first3=N|last4=Dalziel|first4=SR|title=Antenatal corticosteroids for accelerating fetal lung maturation for women at risk of preterm birth.|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=21 March 2017|volume=3|pages=CD004454|pmid=28321847|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD004454.pub3}}</ref> This research evidence is mostly from mid- to high-income countries. However, there is not a lot of research into giving antenatal corticosteroids to women in low-income countries where infections are more common. More research is needed to find out the effects of these steroids on women and babies in low-income countries.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Roberts|first1=D|last2=Brown|first2=J|last3=Medley|first3=N|last4=Dalziel|first4=SR|title=Antenatal corticosteroids for accelerating fetal lung maturation for women at risk of preterm birth.|journal=The Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews|date=21 March 2017|volume=3|pages=CD004454|pmid=28321847|doi=10.1002/14651858.CD004454.pub3}}</ref>
[[Dexamethasone]] and [[betamethasone]] are the corticosteroids used for the purpose although the former is recommended over the latter based on its efficacy, safety, wide availability, and low cost<ref>{{cite journal|title=Dexamethasone versus betamethasone as an antenatal corticosteroid (ACS) |url=http://www.healthynewbornnetwork.org/sites/default/files/resources/ACS%20Beta%20vs%20Dexa%20130820.pdf |work=UN Commission / Born Too soon Care Antenatal Corticosteroids Working Group |date=August 20, 2013 |accessdate=6 January 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140106172834/http://www.healthynewbornnetwork.org/sites/default/files/resources/ACS%20Beta%20vs%20Dexa%20130820.pdf |archivedate=6 January 2014 }}</ref> in spite of some counter-logic.<ref name="pmid16651303">{{cite journal|last=Lee|first=BH|title=Adverse Neonatal Outcomes Associated With Antenatal Dexamethasone Versus Antenatal Betamethasone|journal=Pediatrics|date=1 May 2006|volume=117|issue=5|pages=1503–1510|doi=10.1542/peds.2005-1749|pmid=16651303}}</ref> Betamethasone, on the other hand, is preferred over dexamethasone because it is thought to have better [[prophylaxis]] of [[brain]] softening of premature fetus.<ref>{{cite web|title=Antenatal Steroid Video|url=http://www.ovguide.com/antenatal-steroid-9202a8c04000641f8000000000862be6#}}</ref> They are used with the intention to help the [[lung]]s of a premature [[fetus]] develop before the fetus comes out.<ref name="pmid18245434">{{cite journal |author=Engle WA |title=Surfactant-replacement therapy for respiratory distress in the preterm and term neonate |journal=Pediatrics |volume=121 |issue=2 |pages=419–32 |date=February 2008 |pmid=18245434 |doi=10.1542/peds.2007-3283 |url=http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=18245434}}</ref> They are given when the fetus is expected to be delivered within 24 to 48 hours. Treatment consists of 2 doses of 12 mg of betamethasone given intramuscularly 24 hours apart or 4 doses of 6 mg of dexamethasone given intramuscularly 12 hours apart. Optimal benefit begins 24 hours after initiation of therapy and lasts 7 days.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Recommendations for Use of Antenatal Corticosteroids|url=http://www.perinatology.com/protocols/Steroids.htm|work=perinatology.com|accessdate=6 January 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Medscape Obstetrics|url=http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/408941_9}}{{subscription required}}</ref> Antenatal steroids are currently used up to 36 weeks in some parts of the world [[obstetric]] practice.<ref>{{cite web|title=UK National Health Service |url=http://www.nelm.nhs.uk/en/NeLM-Area/News/2011---April/132/Antenatal-corticosteroids-at-34-36-weeks-gestation-do-not-appear-to-reduce-incidence-of-respiratory-disorders-in-late-preterm-infants |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120903231958/http://www.nelm.nhs.uk/en/NeLM-Area/News/2011---April/132/Antenatal-corticosteroids-at-34-36-weeks-gestation-do-not-appear-to-reduce-incidence-of-respiratory-disorders-in-late-preterm-infants/ |archivedate=2012-09-03 }}</ref>
The time between administration of steroids and delivery may alter the effectiveness of the steroids.<ref name="pmid18450845">{{cite journal |vauthors=McEvoy C, Schilling D, Spitale P, Peters D, O'Malley J, Durand M |title=Decreased respiratory compliance in infants less than or equal to 32 weeks' gestation, delivered more than 7 days after antenatal steroid therapy |journal=Pediatrics |volume=121 |issue=5 |pages=e1032–8 |date=May 2008 |pmid=18450845 |doi=10.1542/peds.2007-2608 |url=http://pediatrics.aappublications.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=18450845}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==Further reading== * [http://www.acadmed.org.my/view_file.cfm?fileid=200 Guideline on the use of Antenatal Corticosteroids to Prevent Respiratory Distress Syndrome] revised August 2001. * {{cite journal|last=Tucker|first=L|author2=Hoff, C|author3= Peevy, K|author4= Brost, B|author5= Holland, S|author6= Calhoun, BC|title=The effects of antenatal steroid use in premature rupture of membranes|journal=The Australian & New Zealand journal of obstetrics & gynaecology|date=Nov 1995|volume=35|issue=4|pages=390–2|pmid=8717561|doi=10.1111/j.1479-828X.1995.tb02149.x}} * [http://apps.who.int/rhl/pregnancy_childbirth/complications/preterm_birth/cd004454_hofmeyrgj_com/en/ Antenatal administration of corticosteroids for women at risk of preterm birth]: WHO Reproductive Health Library

{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2014}}
'''Appreciative inquiry''' ('''AI''') is a model that seeks to engage stakeholders in self-determined change. According to Bushe "AI revolutionized the field of organization development and was a precursor to the rise of positive organization studies and the strengths based movement in American management."<ref>Bushe, G.R. (2013) The appreciative inquiry model. In E.H. Kessler, (ed.) Encyclopedia of Management Theory, (Volume 1, pp. 41-44), Sage Publications, 2013.</ref> It was developed at [[Case Western Reserve University]]'s department of [[organizational behavior]], starting with a 1987 article by [[David Cooperrider]] and Suresh Srivastva. They felt that the overuse of "problem solving" hampered any kind of social improvement, and what was needed were new methods of inquiry that would help generate new ideas and models for how to organize.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Cooperrider, D. L.|author2=Srivastva, S.|year=1987|chapter=Appreciative inquiry in organizational life|editor1=Woodman, R. W.|editor2=Pasmore, W.A.|lastauthoramp=y|title=Research in Organizational Change And Development|volume=Vol. 1|pages=129–169|location=Stamford, CT|publisher=JAI Press}}</ref>
== History == Cooperrider and Srivastva took a social constructionist approach, arguing that organizations are created, maintained and changed by conversations, and claiming that methods of organizing were only limited by people's imaginations and the agreements among them.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Cooperrider, D. L.|author2=Barrett, F.|author3=Srivastva, S.|year=1995|contribution=Social construction and appreciative inquiry: A journey in organizational theory|editor1=Hosking, D.|editor2=Dachler, P.|editor3=Gergen, K.|title=Management and Organization: Relational Alternatives to Individualism|pages=157–200}}</ref>
In 2001, Cooperrider and [[Diana Whitney]] published an article outlining the five principles of AI.<ref>{{cite book|author1=Cooperrider, D.L. |author2=Whitney, D|year=2001|chapter=A positive revolution in change|editor1=Cooperrider, D. L.|editor2=Sorenson, P.|editor3=Whitney, D.|editor4=Yeager, T.|lastauthoramp=y|title=Appreciative Inquiry: An Emerging Direction for Organization Development|pages=9–29|location=Champaign, IL|publisher=Stipes}}</ref>
In 1996, Cooperrider, Whitney and several of their colleagues became centrally involved using AI to mid-wife the creation of the United Religions Initiative, a global organization dedicated to promoting grassroots interfaith cooperation for peace, justice and healing. This early partnership between URI and AI is chronicled in Birth of a Global Community: Appreciative Inquiry in Action by Charles Gibbs and Sally Mahé. AI was also used in the first (1999) and subsequent meetings of business leaders that created the UN's Global Compact.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://appreciativeinquiry.case.edu/intro/commentFeb05.cfm|title=Current Commentary on AI and Positive Change|author=Cooperrider, David|work=AI Commons|accessdate=July 6, 2016}}</ref> In another of the early applications, Cooperrider and Whitney taught AI to employees of GTE (now part of Verizon) resulting in improvements in employees' support for GTE's business direction and. as a part of continuous process improvement generated both improvements in revenue collection and cost savings earning GTE an [[ASTD]] award for the best organisational change program in the US in 1997."<ref name="Bushe 2005">{{cite journal|author1=Bushe, G.R.|author2=Kassam, A.|year=2005|title=When is appreciative inquiry transformational? A meta-case analysis|journal=Journal of Applied Behavioral Science|volume=41|issue=2|pages=161–181|displayauthors=etal|url=http://www.gervasebushe.ca/ai-meta.pdf}}</ref>{{rp|176}}
On May 8, 2010, Suresh Srivastva died.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.taosinstitute.net/suresh-srviastva|title=Suresh Srviastva|work=The Taos Institute|accessdate=July 6, 2016}}</ref>
Gervase Bushe, a researcher on the topic, published a 2011 review of the model, including its processes, critiques, and evidence.<ref>{{cite book|author=Bushe, G. R.|layurl=http://www.gervasebushe.ca/AITC.pdf|chapter=Appreciative Inquiry: Theory and Critique|year=2011|editor1=Boje, D.|editor2=Burnes, B. |editor3=Hassard, J.|title=The Routledge Companion To Organizational Change |pages=87–103|location=Oxford, UK|publisher=Routledge}}</ref> He also published a history of the model in 2012.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://www.gervasebushe.ca/Foundations_AI.pdf|title = Foundations of Appreciative Inquiry|date = 2012|website = Bushe's website|publisher = Appreciative Practitioner|last = Bushe|first = Gervase}}</ref>
== Basis and principles ==
According to Bushe, AI "advocates collective inquiry into the best of what is, in order to imagine what could be, followed by collective design of a desired future state that is compelling and thus, does not require the use of incentives, coercion or persuasion for planned change to occur."<ref name="Bushe, G.R. 2013">{{cite book|author=Bushe, G.R.|year=2013|url=http://www.gervasebushe.ca/the_AI_model.pdf|title=The Appreciative Inquiry Model|editor= Kessler, E.|work=The Encyclopedia of Management Theory|publisher= Sage Publications}}</ref>
The model is based on the assumption that the questions we ask will tend to focus our attention in a particular direction, that organizations evolve in the direction of the questions they most persistently and passionately ask.<ref>Cooperrider, D.L. & Whitney, D (2005) A positive revolution in change: Appreciative inquiry. In Cooperrider, D. L. Sorenson, P., Yeager, T. & Whitney, D. (eds.) Appreciative Inquiry: Foundations in Positive Organization Development (pp.9-33). Champaign, IL: Stipes.</ref> In the mid 80's most methods of assessing and evaluating a situation and then proposing solutions were based on a ''deficiency'' model, predominantly asking questions such as "What are the problems?", "What's wrong?" or "What needs to be fixed?". Instead of asking "What's the problem?", others couched the question in terms of "challenges", which still focused on deficiency, on what needs to be fixed or solved.<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Case Western Reserve University's Weatherhead School of Management|url=http://appreciativeinquiry.case.edu/|title=The Appreciative Inquiry Commons}}</ref> Appreciative Inquiry was the first serious managerial method to refocus attention on what works, the positive core, and on what people really care about. Today, these ways of approaching organizational change are common<ref>Bushe, G.R. & Marhsak, R.M. (2015) ''Dialogic Organization Development: The Theory and Practice of Organizational Transformation.'' Oakdland, CA: Berrett-Koehler.</ref>
The five principles of AI are:<ref name="Bushe, G.R. 2013" /> # The ''constructionist principle'' proposes that what we believe to be true determines what we do, and thought and action emerge from relationships. Through the language and discourse of day to day interactions, people co-construct the organizations they inhabit. The purpose of inquiry is to stimulate new ideas, stories and images that generate new possibilities for action. # The ''principle of simultaneity'' proposes that as we inquire into human systems we change them and the seeds of change, the things people think and talk about, what they discover and learn, are implicit in the very first questions asked. Questions are never neutral, they are fateful, and social systems move in the direction of the questions they most persistently and passionately discuss. # The ''poetic principle'' proposes that organizational life is expressed in the stories people tell each other every day, and the story of the organization is constantly being co-authored. The words and topics chosen for inquiry have an impact far beyond just the words themselves. They invoke sentiments, understandings, and worlds of meaning. In all phases of the inquiry effort is put into using words that point to, enliven and inspire the best in people. # The ''anticipatory principle'' posits that what we do today is guided by our image of the future. Human systems are forever projecting ahead of themselves a horizon of expectation that brings the future powerfully into the present as a mobilizing agent. Appreciative inquiry uses artful creation of positive imagery on a collective basis to refashion anticipatory reality. # The ''positive principle'' proposes that momentum and sustainable change requires positive affect and social bonding. Sentiments like hope, excitement, inspiration, camaraderie and joy increase creativity, openness to new ideas and people, and cognitive flexibility. They also promote the strong connections and relationships between people, particularly between groups in conflict, required for collective inquiry and change.
Some researchers believe that excessive focus on dysfunctions can actually cause them to become worse or fail to become better.<ref>{{cite web|author=Wallis, Claudia|date=January 17, 2005|work=Time Magazine|title=The Science of Happiness|url=http://www.authentichappiness.sas.upenn.edu/images/TimeMagazine/Time-Happiness.pdf|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060711093607/http://www.authentichappiness.sas.upenn.edu/images/timemagazine/Time-Happiness.pdf|archivedate=July 11, 2006 |deadurl=y}}</ref> By contrast, AI argues, when all members of an organization are motivated to understand and value the most favourable features of its culture, it can make rapid improvements.<ref name="new-paradigm.co.uk">{{cite web|title=Background|url=http://www.new-paradigm.co.uk/Appreciative.htm|work=New Paradigm|accessdate=July 6, 2016}}</ref>
Strength-based methods are used in the creation of organizational development strategy and implementation of organizational effectiveness tactics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mt-online.com/component/content/article/77-february2007/228-building-strength-based-organizations.html|title=Building Strength-Based Organizations|first=Scott|last=Franklin|date=February 1, 2007|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928205741/http://www.mt-online.com/component/content/article/77-february2007/228-building-strength-based-organizations.html|archivedate=September 28, 2011|deadurl=y|work=Maintenance Technology}}</ref> The ''appreciative'' mode of inquiry often relies on interviews to qualitatively understand the organization's potential strengths by looking at an organization's experience and its potential; the objective is to elucidate the assets and personal motivations that are its strengths.
Bushe has argued that mainstream proponents of AI focus too much attention on "the positive" and not enough on the transformation that AI can bring about through generating new ideas and the will to act on them.<ref name="Bushe 2005"/><ref>{{cite journal|author=Bushe, G.R.|year=2007|title=Appreciative inquiry is not (just) about the positive|journal=Organization Development Practitioner|volume=39|issue=4|pages=30–35|url=http://www.gervasebushe.ca/AI_pos.pdf}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.gervasebushe.ca/AI_generativity.pdf|title=Generative process, generative outcome: The transformational potential of appreciative inquiry|last=|first=|work=Organizational Generativity: The Appreciative Inquiry Summit and a Scholarship of Transformation|publisher=Emerald Group Publishing Limited|year=2013|isbn=|series=Advances in Appreciative Inquiry|volume=4|location=Bingley, UK|pages=|via=|author=Bushe, G.R.|editor1=D.L. Cooperrider|editor2=D.P. Zandee|editor3=L.N. Godwin|editor4=M. Avital|editor5=B. Boland|pp=89–113}}</ref> In a 2010 comparative study in a school district he found that even in cases where no change occurred participants were highly positive during the AI process.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Bushe, G.R.|year=2010|url=http://www.gervasebushe.ca/comparative_case.pdf|title=A comparative case study of appreciative inquiries in one organization: Implications for practice|journal=Revista de Cercetare si Interventie Sociala / Review of Research and Social Intervention|series=Special Issue on Appreciative Inquiry|volume=29|pages=7–24}}</ref> What distinguished those sites that experienced transformational changes was the creation of new ideas that gave people new ways to address old problems. He argues that for transformational change to occur, AI must address problems that concern people enough to want to change. However, AI addresses them not through problem-solving, but through generative images.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Bushe, G.R.|year=2013|title= Dialogic OD: A theory of practice|journal=Organization Development Practitioner, special issue on advances in Dialogic Organization Development|volume=45|issue=1|pages= 10–16}}</ref> Some of this is covered in a 90-minute discussion about AI, positivity and generativity by Bushe and Dr. Ron Fry of Case Western, at the 2012 World Appreciative Inquiry Conference.<ref>{{cite web|title=Webcast Plenary Session 6: Prof. Dr. Ronald Fry and Prof. Dr. Gervase Bushe|url=http://www.2012waic.com/webcast-plenary-session-6-prof-dr-ronald-fry-and-prof-dr-gervase-bushe/}}</ref>
== Distinguishing features ==
The following table comes from the Cooperrider and Whitney (2001){{full|date=September 2018}} article and is used to describe some of the distinctions between AI and approaches to organizational development not based on what they call positive potential:<ref>{{cite web|publisher=Case Western Reserve University|work=Appreciative Inquiry Commons|url=http://appreciativeinquiry.case.edu/intro/whatisai.cfm|title=What is Appreciative Inquiry?|accessdate=July 6, 2016}}</ref>
{| class="wikitable" |- ! Problem Solving !! Appreciative inquiry |- | 1. "Felt Need," identification of Problem || 1. Appreciating & Valuing the Best of "What Is" |- | 2. Analysis of Causes || 2. Envisioning "What Might Be" |- | 3. Analysis & Possible Solutions || 3. Dialoguing "What Should Be" |- | 4. Action Planning (Treatment) || |- | '''Basic Assumption:''' An Organization is a Problem to be Solved || '''Basic Assumption:''' An Organization is a Mystery to be Embraced |}
Appreciative inquiry attempts to use ways of asking questions and envisioning the future in order to foster positive relationships and build on the present potential of a given person, organization or situation. The most common model utilizes a cycle of four processes, which focus on what it calls: #''DISCOVER:'' The identification of organizational processes that work well. #''DREAM:'' The envisioning of processes that would work well in the future. #''DESIGN:'' Planning and prioritizing processes that would work well. #''DESTINY'' (or ''DEPLOY''): The implementation (execution) of the proposed design.<ref name="new-paradigm.co.uk"/>
The aim is to build – or rebuild – organizations around what works, rather than trying to fix what doesn't. AI practitioners try to convey this approach as the opposite of problem solving.
==Implementing AI==
There are a variety of approaches to implementing appreciative inquiry, including mass-mobilised interviews and a large, diverse gathering called an Appreciative Inquiry Summit.<ref>http://www.positivechange.org/downloads/AI_and_Spiritual_ResonanceV.Final.pdf{{dead link|date=July 2016}}</ref> These approaches involve bringing large, diverse groups of people together to study and build upon the ''best'' in an organization or community.
== Uses ==
AI is used in organizational development and as a [[Management consulting|consultancy]] tool in an attempt to bring about strategic change. It has been applied in businesses, health care bodies, social non-profit organizations, educational institutions, and government operations.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://appreciativeinquiry.case.edu/join/easySubmit.cfm|title=Easy Submit: Do you have a story, document, tool, event to share?|work= AI Commons|accessdate=July 6, 2016}}</ref> Although originating in the US, it is also used in the UK – for example in the [[National Support Teams]] and around the world. Since 2000, ''The AI Practitioner'', a quarterly publication, has described applications in a variety of settings around the world.
AI has various business applications and can effectively be used to elicit information from stakeholders.<ref>https://pdfs.semanticscholar.org/fe15/76385b5e4767493f3d51224c721494b6ec10.pdf</ref> Positivity is paired with a group consensus to envision and begin producing an optimistic future based on existing strengths and successes. As seen in [[Harbarian process modeling]], AI has been used in [[Business process modeling]] to elicit information about an organization's present state and desired future state.
In Vancouver, AI is being used by the [[Dalai Lama Center for Peace and Education]]. The Center, which was founded by the [[14th Dalai Lama|Dalai Lama]] and [[Victor Chan]], is using AI to facilitate compassionate communities.<ref>{{cite web|title=Heart-Mind Inquiry|work=Dalai Lama Center|url=http://dalailamacenter.org/programs/programs-development/appreciative-inquiry|accessdate=July 6, 2016}}</ref>

Gergen]] instrumental in [[social constructionism]] and the concept of generativity *[[David Cooperrider]] originated the theory of appreciative inquiry in his 1986 doctoral dissertation. * [[Organization development]] * [[Social constructionism]] * [[Complexity theory and organizations]]
